did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Records, 1901-1980. This collection includes material regarding company founder Carlos C. Jacome; material regarding company president Alex G. Jacome; company history materials, including photocopies of news clippings; business correspondence; accounting and finance material (mainly business ledgers from 1903 to 1973, including a large payroll ledger covering the years 1939-1950); material related to the Hispanic fraternal benefit society Alianza Hispano-Americana; photographs, including images of Jacome family members, La Bonanza General Store (interior and exterior), and Jacome's Department Store (interior and exterior); real estate documents (legal documents, plans, and blueprints); and scrapbooks.

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Jacome's Department Store records (MS 405). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Jacome's Department Store began in 1896 as La Bonanza General Store. Company founder Carlos C. Jacome initially partnered with Loreto Carrillo and opened a store located at 84 West Congress Street, Tucson, Arizona. Jacome then partnered with Genaro S. Manzo in 1902. During their business partnership, Jacome and Manzo were involved with the Alianza Hispano-Americana, a fraternal benefit society for Mexican-Americans. The partnership between Jacome and Manzo was dissolved in 1913 and the store remained within the Jacome family until 1980 (Manzo later returned to work for the store as an employee). In addition to operating La Bonanza, Jacome was involved in Arizona territorial politics. He was the only person of Mexican-descent selected for Arizona's constitutional convention in 1910 and his active membership with the convention contributed to Arizona's obtaining of statehood in 1912. The store's name was changed from La Bonanza to Jacome's Department Store c. 1921 and it was incorporated in 1928. Carlos's son, Alex G. Jacome graduated from the University of Arizona with the degree Bachelor of Science in Business Administration in 1927 and served internships with department stores in New York City and Laredo, Texas before returning to Tucson to work at Jacome's. Alex was named vice-president of the company in 1928. The company's board of directors installed Alex as president upon the death of Carlos in 1932. Alex maintained ties with the University of Arizona throughout his life. He established and oversaw a scholarship fund named in honor of his father. He received the University of Arizona Distinguished Citizen Award in 1966 and he was awarded an honorary Doctor of Laws degree in 1974. Over the years, Alex served on several boards of directors. He also was a member of the Arizona Board of Regents from 1952 to 1961. One of the highlights of Alex's tenure as president of Jacome's was the construction and grand opening of a $1,000,000 store at Stone and Pennington in Tucson in 1951. Alex became chairman of the board of Jacome's in 1972 and his son, Alex F. Jacome, was named president of the company. Alex G. Jacome died in 1980. Jacome's Department Store closed in April of 1980 and its assets were divided among the stockholders.

list.item: Jacome's Department Store, 87-93 W. Congress, c. 1921-1951 (expanded 1937)
Jacome's Department Store, Stone and Pennington, 1951-1980 (expanded 1957)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into ten series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Records, 1901-1980. Collection consists of the records of Jacome's Department Store, a family-owned business in operation in Tucson, Arizona from 1896 to 1980. The collection contains the papers of company founder Carlos C. Jacome and the papers of his son, long-time company president Alex G. Jacome. A portion of Alex G. Jacome's papers includes personal correspondence with notable politicians including Senators Barry Goldwater and Dennis DeConcini, and Congressmen Morris and Stewart Udall. The collection also includes material relating to company history, including photocopies of news clippings (of note, there is a brief 1950 Time magazine article detailing the building of the new Stone and Pennington store in Tucson); business correspondence; and accounting and finance records. The accounting and finance records, mainly in the form of business ledgers from 1903 to 1973, make up the bulk of the collection. Additionally, the collection includes material related to the Hispanic fraternal benefit society Alianza Hispano-Americana; photographs, including images of Jacome family members, La Bonanza General Store (interior and exterior), and Jacome's Department Store (interior and exterior); real estate documents (legal documents, plans, and blueprints); and scrapbooks (the scrapbooks mainly contain photographs, news clippings, and store advertisements). Several items in the collection are in Spanish-these items consist mostly of correspondence or news clippings.

scopecontent.p: This series concerns Carlos C. Jacome, founder of La Bonanza General Store in Tucson, Arizona, which later became Jacome's Department Store. It contains legal documents; correspondence relating to several mining stake claims owned by Carlos; correspondence with family members-particularly with relatives living in Los Angeles and San Francisco, California; correspondence with his attorney, John B. Wright; miscellaneous postcards; and a savings book for an account with the Southern Arizona Bank and Trust Company.

did.unittitle: Miscellaneous; Administrator of Francisco Estrada Estate. 1907-1908
Personal Correspondence; Wright, John B., Attorney. 1907-1913
Savings Book; Southern Arizona Bank and Trust Company. 1921

scopecontent.p: This series concerns Alex G. Jacome, long-time president of the company and son of Carlos C. Jacome. It contains material regarding board memberships and public service activities; material regarding the bestowal of an honorary degree on Alex by the University of Arizona; speeches; and personal correspondence, including correspondence with Arizona political figures such as Senators Carl Hayden, Paul Fannin, Barry Goldwater, and Dennis DeConcini, and Congressmen Morris and Stewart Udall. Some of the correspondence is in Spanish.

scopecontent.p: The Company History Series contains material about the company's fiftieth anniversary, business associate Genaro S. Manzo, news articles and advertising regarding the Stone and Pennington store that opened in 1951, news clippings relating to the company, Jacome's Department Store circulars, price lists, and wholesalers' catalogs. Several of the news clippings are in Spanish. [Note: Additional Company History items are located in Series 10: Oversized Materials].

scopecontent.p: The bulk of the Business Correspondence series is composed of miscellaneous correspondence. The series also contains correspondence with particular wholesalers as well as correspondence on the subject of store events such as Christmas displays and the 1951 new store grand opening for the Stone and Pennington store. Some of the correspondence is in Spanish.

did.unittitle: Jacome's New Store Grand Opening (1 of 2). 1951
Jacome's New Store Grand Opening (2 of 2). 1951
Southern Arizona Bank and Trust Company as Trustee for Frank Jacome. 1936

scopecontent.p: The bulk of the Accounting and Finance series consists of bound business ledgers with handwritten entries. Some business ledgers from the Hayden branch store are included in this series. Also, the series contains some statements and reports prepared for the Pima County and state tax commissions. [Note: an oversized payroll ledger for the years 1939-1950 is found in Series 10: Oversized Materials].

scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence between Carlos C. Jacome, Genaro S. Manzo, and other members of Alianza Hispano-Americana (AHA). The series also contains a bank book, financial statements, publications, and miscellaneous documents concerning AHA activities. Many items are in Spanish.

The Photographs series contains dated and undated photographs including images of the Stone and Pennington store while under construction, festivities surrounding the grand opening of the Stone and Pennington store in 1951 (interior and exterior), the unveiling of the Jacome's 58th anniversary logo, and miscellaneous store window displays. Also included are miscellaneous photographs of Alex G. Jacome dining with Mexican government officials as well as picture postcards of family members. [Note: Additional photographs are found in Series 10: Oversized Materials].

The Real Estate series contains insurance policy information; legal documents including abstracts of title, contracts, deeds, leases, mortgages, and zoning provisions; and plans and blueprints for new stores and the expansion of existing stores. [Note: Additional building plans are located in Series 10: Oversized Material].

scopecontent.p: The Scrapbook series contains a scrapbook highlighting the activities of the Jacome's Hi Board High School Fashion Club; two scrapbooks contemporaneous with the building of the new store at Stone and Pennington Streets in 1951, and a historical overview of the store at Stone and Pennington put together in 1967. The scrapbooks include photographs, news clippings, radio scripts, advertisements, and a few 35mm slides.

did.unittitle: The Story of Jacome's Modern Store at Stone and Pennington. 1950-1951
The Story of Jacome's Modern Store at Stone and Pennington. 1967

scopecontent.p: The Oversized Materials series contains items from other series that are too large to fit in standard record cartons. Items include a payroll ledger covering the years 1939-1950, advertising artwork, and several large photographs. The photographs include an undated poster-sized print of an aerial view of downtown Tucson, undated poster-prints of the exteriors and interiors of La Bonanza General Store and Jacome's Department Store, an undated poster-sized print of the Park Brewery in Tucson, and several large inscribed photographs of Mexican governmental officials given to Alex G. Jacome between the years 1955-1979.
